sub_title: Scientist | Ambagon Therapeutics | PhD in Chemical Biology
summary: Enthusiastic young chemical biologist with a passion for molecular interactions and early drug discovery. Motivated by challenging scientific projects at the forefront of interdisciplinary research towards the development of new medicines. Thrives by reaching successes from teamwork and collaboration, with an entrepreneurial and pioneering mindset!

profile_positions.description: Biotech startup focused on the development of small molecule cancer drugs by stabilizing protein-protein interactions.
profile_positions.title: Scientist

profile_positions.description: The modulation of protein-protein interactions (PPIs) by small molecules has risen to the highest ranks amongst promising strategies in modern drug development. Whereas PPI inhibitors have taken the stage though, my research aims to tackle the challenge of following Nature's inspiration and focusing on PPI stabilization! The results described in my PhD dissertation provide innovative fragment-based strategies for the discovery of small molecule PPI stabilizers, exemplarily illustrated for several interactions of the hub protein 14-3-3. Besides yielding a range of chemical starting points ready for further development, the scientific insights of this research are anticipated to empower systemic stabilization as a drug discovery strategy.
profile_positions.title: PhD Student

profile_positions.description: During this final MSc internship I initiated a project as a collaboration between the Chemical Biology lab at TU/e and the Small Molecule Discovery Centre at UCSF in which we screened for small molecule modulators of protein-protein interactions using a specialized fragment-based drug discovery approach.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Researcher

profile_positions.description: During my MSc graduation I worked on a project as a collaboration between the lab of Luc Brunsveld in Chemical Biology and the Wilbert Zwart lab at the Netherlands Cancer Institute (NKI). The main goal of this work was to elucidate the dual binding mechanism of two phytoestrogens on the Estrogen Receptor alpha, and the implications in the hormone-dependent type of breast cancer.
profile_positions.title: Graduate Student MSc

company.name: NRSCB (Netherlands Research School of Chemical Biology)

profile_positions.company: NRSCB (Netherlands Research School of Chemical Biology)
profile_positions.description: This honors program in Chemical Biology is a collaboration between participating universities of Leiden, Nijmegen, Groningen and Eindhoven for which a few students were selected from each university. Over the course of the academic year 2013-2014 we followed a specialized course at each of the universities at the end of which we wrote a research proposal in the specific fields.
profile_positions.title: Research School Participant

profile_positions.description: During my time in the Spinoza Institute - founded by prof. Bert Meijer after being awarded the NWO Spinoza Prize - I worked on the development and production of supramolecular biomaterials for translational research and applications in regenerative medicine.
profile_positions.title: Junior Researcher
